reviewText: The YENTL (DIRECTOR'S EXTENDED EDITION) 2-DVD SET is what a DVD set should be.A dream production that Barbra Streisand carried around for years, based in part on a story by Isaac Bashevis SingerYentl the Yeshiva Boy, which she dedicated to her father. When the movie came out in 1983, Streisand became one of the few celebs (if not the first) to star, direct, produce and sing in one film.The story is about a woman who disguises herself as a boy to study the Talmud and takes place during the turn of the last century in Europe, where women were forbidden to learn or read scholarly books. Yentl changes her name to Anschel, cuts her hair and dresses like a man, and then gets tangled up in a three-way love affair that really challenges the notion of what is love and gender.At its heart--both in the film and in reality--YENTL is really about hope and awakenings and the pursuit of a dream, not to mention the challenging of rules and ideals that are unjust. Amy Irving and Mandy Patinkin deliver stellar performances. And of course, all would not be right without Barbra Streisand's creative vision and direction.=============== DVD 1 ================** INTRO ** Barbra introduces the movie and the inclusion of additional footage added to the extended version and explains why the scenes were cut.** MOVIE ** Option to play either the extended director's cut (which includes added deleted scenes) and the theatrical version.** ADDITIONAL DELETED SCENES ** Those not included in the extended cut=============== DVD 2 ================** INTRO ** (3:00-minutes) Barbra explains the process of directing etc.** DIRECTOR'S REEL ** (6:50-minutes) This shows unedited footage of the actors during a scene as the director pushes to get the right emotional response.** AMATEUR VIDEO OF REHEARSALS FOR MUSICAL NUMBERS **This is very interesting to watch as it shows the amount of preparation Streisand did before going into the actual production of the movie. Kind of like watching live story boards. There's an option to "PLAY ALL" or "SCENE SELECTION" and here's the time in minutes and the songs.---Intro 1:30---Were Is It Written? 5:40/ Comparison to film 5:13---No Wonder Reprise. (Rehearsal/Comparison) 3:30---Tomorrow Night. 5:00/ Comparison 5:35---Will Someone Ever Look At Me That Way? (Rehearsal/Comparison) 2:30** DELETED SONGS IN STORY BOARDS **---The Moon & I. 3:30---Several Sins A Day. 3:30** AMATEUR CONCEPT FILM ** 8:30Plays with or without Barbra's narration and shows her scouting locations and choosing the look of set pieces etc.** MY WONDERFUL CAST & CREW ** 7:20This is a nice personal touch that pays homage to all of the people who worked on this film, especially those behind the scenes, and plays against the song "Piece Of Sky."** STILL GALLERIES **Includes photos from the production, portraits, behind-the-scenes, and the recording studio.All-in-all I'm happy with the movie and the extras that came with it. I wish other Streisand movies were given the same treatment--in particularThe Owl And The PussycatandWhat's Up, Doc?, two movies that I love! But I recommend this set to any Barbra fan, but you probably already have it.

reviewText: YENTL is Barbra Streisand's most personal and important movie.  The film features Streisand the performer, Streisand the director, Streisand the screenwriter and Streisand the producer.  To say that YENTL was a labour of love would be an understatement.The plot, based on the original story of "Yentl the Yeshiva Boy" by Isaac Bashevis Singer, concerns a young woman in Eastern Europe at the dawn of the 20th century.  Since women are forbidden from knowledge and study, Yentl is tutored in secret by her loving father (Nehemiah Persoff).  When her father suddenly dies, a desolate yet defiant Yentl runs away from her small village, disguises herself as a man and enrols to study with a community of scholars.  There she meets the charismatic Avigdor (Mandy Patinkin).  She finds herself falling in love with him, but he is smitten by beautiful Hadass (Amy Irving).  However, Hadass and Avigdor are forbidden to marry.  Avigdor proposes that Yentl enter into a marriage-of-convenience with Hadass so he may continue to see her.  All the while continuing with the charade of being a man, Yentl's world precariously begins to topple...Michel Legrand, Alan and Marilyn Bergman's musical score adds a lot of heartfelt emotion and depth to the proceedings.  Barbra Streisand handles the complicated title role with finess and style.  Patinkin and Irving are glorious and Persoff is superb.  A classic for the whole family.

reviewText: There are two names that are equally synonomous with this piece: Isaac Bashevis Singer (the author of the short story and co-author of the play) and Barbra Streisand. In history, no other person has taken on so many jobs for the creation of one film as Streisand did for this one. "Yentyl" was ten years in the making. though Streisand obtained the rights for the project ion 1969, hoping for it to be the film she made after "Funny Girl"  When reading the short story one would think, ":This could never be made into a movie" However, Streisand covered all of these issues by using voice overs to express inner monologue; somewhere along the way she decided to contract Micheal Legrand and Alan and Marilyn Bergman to turn these monologues into songs and since Streissand, who wrote, produced, directed and edited this film, also played the title rolel, was suddenly singing the most remarkable film music ever written in history. (I include ":The Wizard of Oz", "Singing in The Rain", "Jaws" and "Fame"- I do not speak of Boradway trnsfers to film such as "West Side Story" or "Sweeney Todd") So through the systematic solving of some big problems we now have one of the finest film scores and film songs in history.The story is remarkable and every element of the film is accurate. Not only do we see the Jewish life in Poland fifteen years before before the first world war but we see the struggle between the role of men and women. It is her desire to learn and to read and be more than a cook and housewife that causes the young girl to disguise herself as a Yeshiva Boy(student) cut her hair and travel to the big city to enroll in school.Yentyl takes on the name Anshul there and parts of life that she never imagined opened up to her. This film contains none of the usual folly that ensues as a result of cross dressing tactics; it is not a comedy and though the same things may well happen here that one sees in La Cage Aux Folles and The Bird Cage, they are depicted with the hard pain of the reality. Even this is brought to light through the artistry of Streisands work.The film begins by following a white down feather along a flowwing creek aqnd post rain running puddle, through a market place and into the scene. The detail is precise and this same precision remains until the very last cut which is a camera at sea level looking upon an ocean liner bound for America after Streisand has sung the most amazingly difficult and moving piece of music in the film. The composition of this piece (It is called "A Piece of Sky") is such that the composers used  fragments of many other songs in the score and fused them together over which they lay this fresh new song. Streisand holds the final note for a total of ten measures; it is a B natural, the note that falls directly on Streisands passagio, and therefore, in full chest voice, has the most intensity that any sung note can have. Composer Jule Syne found this piece ofStreisand twenty five years earlier and used it for her voice with the first act finale of "Funny Girl" and indeed, Streisands incredible breath control and support is what has made her so famous because frankly, nobody does it better. She uses the exact same muscles and control early in the film, alone by a campfire after her father's death as she steals away to the city in a remarkable song called "Papa, Can You Hear Me?" Every trained singer who hears this sits, slightly tense, aware that she took no safety breath and that it is humanly impossible to sustain sound that softly for that long, yet, even after fifty years of listening to Streisand sing, she continues to do it and continues to be modest about it. She continues to astonish us.Mandy Patinkin, fresh off the stage from "Evita" and just before his return for "Sunday In The Park With George" does a remarkable job with the co-star role, playing Avigdor, Yentyl's study partner with whom Yentyl falls in love and Avigdor develops a warmth friendship as though this young boy were his own brother. Mandy Patkinkin has prooven himself time after time to be a remarkable actor and in this film he is no different except that Streisand has managed to block the cameras to intensify emotional moments, whether they are building to a fight or thy are creeping around a dining table allowing us to spy on the emotions of each individual. Patinkin is very aware of the camera staging and plays with it beautifully.Many critics have complained that Streisand did not have Patinkin sing, and indeed Mandy Patinkin is one of America's finest tenors, but their complaints over this are in print because of a lack of understanding and perhaps even idiocy as I have already explained that the music in this film is to allow us ONLY into the mind of the individual who is hiding so much about her true self. If you wish to hear Patinkin sing, buy a CD (I recommend "Sunday In The PArk With George")"Yentyl" is period perfect, from properties, costumes, sets and dialects to the instruments in the orchestra. If the instrument wasn;t used in Eastern Europe in 1892 or wasn;t invented then it is not here. The harmony is all modal, utilizing much from the Jewish services including some beautify string and vocal parts using the Kaddish that underscore her father's fiuneral and another temple scene.This film was fairly wellk snubbed at the oscars, but then Barbra Streisand has been fairly well snubbed by the Oscars herself for her entire career. She won her first Tony Award at age 19, the same age that she won her first Grammy Award. She won The Oscar for best acress for "Funny Girl" and best original song for "Evergreen" but Streisand is to film direction what Barbara Walters is to journalism and Shirley Jackson is to serious fiction. Had this film been directed by Billy Wilder and come out as good it would have swept the Oscars, instead it swept the Golden Globes where Barbra Streisand became the first woman to ever win as Best Director.. Proof of this is in the film "Prince of TIdes" which would come about seven years later where Streisand directed Nick Nolte and the film was nominated in almost every catagory ExCEPT for best direction. At the Oscars, ":Yentyl" was famously snubbed" With "The P{rince of Tides" it became clear that it was Streisand whom the Oscars were subbing.The opening of the Oscars that year had BillyCrystal singing new lyrics to "Don;t Rain On My Parade" and during the bridge (with the one-four time measure after each phrase) Billy sang, "Did this film direct itself?" The conductor's hands remained up, not moving,Billy stood still and the audience roared with laughtter evolving into a standing ovation. "The Prince of Tides" was nomionated for seven Accademy Awards but 1992 "The Silence of The Lambs" swept all catagories making it (with "One flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest") one of two films in history to win virtually every single major catagory.Thus I can say that ":Yentyl's" lack of oscars should not deter you; should not disqualify it as being one of the finest films of the post Vietnam era and certainly one of Streisand's greatest efforts.
summary: a Masterpiece for art; a necessity for history

reviewText: It took me many, many years to see YENTL and I am so glad that I finally did.  What an amazing accomplishment for Barbra Streisand, in this, her directorial debut.  YENTL went on to win a well-deserved Academy Award for Best Original Song Score.  This is the film adaptation of the story written by Isaac Bashevis Singer.  It takes a look at the determination of one young woman, Yentl, and her quest for education in 1904 Eastern Europe, when young women in her village were forbidden to become literate. Raised by a Rabbi father (Nehemiah Persoff), the young girl learns the sacred text of the Telmud in secret, when the shades are drawn, and under his watchful eye.  Yentl is headstrong and fiercely determined to learn at any cost, in the face of the values imposed on women by a male dominated society.  When her father passes away, Yentl decides to cut her hair, don trousers in the guise of a young boy, in order to finally have a chance at the education she hungers for.  On the way, she encounters Avigdor (Mandy Patinkin), a fellow classmate, and his beautiful fiancee, Hadass (Amy Irving, who received a well-earned Oscar nomination for the role).This film is filled with beautiful music (this includes the ever popular "Papa, Can You Hear Me"), strong and engaging acting and beautiful artistic direction.  My only complaint is that this hasn't been released and distributed more widely on DVD in the United States.  This film is worthy of preservation and carries a great message about the triumph of the human spirit and the emancipation of women in the face of great obstacles and social oppression.  We are truly privileged that Ms. Streisand brought YENTL to the screen with such success.  Highly reccomended.
summary: one of the best films of Barbra Streisand's career.....

reviewText: The 25th Anniversary Edition DVD of Barbra Streisand's 1983 directorial debut is here at last, and it is chock full of bonus features. Highlights include a new introduction by Streisand, a commentary track from her as well as the film's executive producer Rusty Lemorande, and most intriguingly, eleven deleted scenes. As the first of only three films she has directed (so far), Streisand's labor of love still holds up as a charming turn-of-the-last-century fable that blends a contemporary sense of its three principal characters with an elaborately orchestrated soundtrack.The movie plays out very much like the way she uniquely sings a song - beautifully lush, emotionally intimate and a bit overdone albeit forgivably so. Regardless, what makes this film genuinely successful is the heartfelt manner in which Streisand chooses to tell her version of Isaac Bashevis Singer's short story, Yentl the Yeshiva Boy. Co-written by her and English playwright Jack Rosenthal, the plot focuses on a young Jewish woman in Eastern Europe who has been tutored on the Talmud by her scholarly father. Since women are forbidden to receive a formal education, it remains a clandestine vocation until her father dies at which point she cuts off her hair, dresses like a boy, and seeks passage to the nearest Talmudic academy. En route, under the guise of Anshel, she meets Avigdor with whom she falls in love. Complications ensue since Yentl cannot reveal her true identity to Avigdor, who is in love with the comely Hadass, but Hadass becomes attracted to Anshel through the machinations of Avigdor when he is forbidden by Hadass' father to marry her.Streisand directs this romantic roundelay with warmth and sincerity rather than cheap laughs, and naturally, as a means to bridge her dramatic interpretations of the big ballads penned by Michel Legrand and her favorite lyricists, Alan & Marilyn Bergman. The songs reflect interior monologues to express how Yentl feels in any given situation, and the conjoining technique works beautifully since the songs are so well crafted and Streisand is in glorious, emotionally unfettered voice. The best are the solitarily prayerfulPapa Can You Hear Me?under a starry night sky, the lusciously unrequited passion drivingThe Way He Makes Me Feel, and the triumphant declaration ofNo Matter What Happens. As expected from as meticulous a novice filmmaker as Streisand, the production values are superior, especially David Watkin's burnished cinematography and Roy Walker's production design.In truth, Streisand looks too old as Yentl the yearning woman, but in full drag as Anshel, she looks ideally boyish. As she traverses genders back and forth with a fumbling grace, it is probably the most subtle acting she has done in films. Mandy Patinkin, then more famous as a singing Ché Guevara inEvita, makes for a potent romantic lead bringing a surly intellect and smoldering passion to Avigdor. As the third corner in the triangle, Amy Irving convincingly plays the subservient bride-to-be with sly intelligence. Veteran character actor Nehemiah Persoff (Some Like It Hot) makes his few poignant scenes count as Yentl's father. A bit overlong at 132 minutes, it isn't a perfect film but it remains an impressive directorial debut and the first film that validates Streisand's exalted standing as a multi-hyphenate entertainment figure.
summary: Finally on DVD, Streisand's Prodigious Labor of Love Still Holds Up Due to Her Heartfelt Approach

reviewText: Traditionally, society has been the master of everyone and limits an individual's abilities to their stereotyped expectations. Even in so-called free societies, people are confined to a certain status. Had Yentl not become a him, as Anshel, she could have never entered the ranks of the more progressive thinkers who by social decree had to be male. Watching her skills in handling the challenges of her male role was intriguing as long as this cinema critic could overlook her not being noticed for her femininity. However, there are guys who have the same mannerisms and features society has marked as girlish, and some gals could definitely be seen as guys in certain settings. So Yentl's portrayal of a guy is not that farfetched. It is society that really has the blind eyes in not acknowledging these stereotypical contradictions and letting people achieve the goals that could enrich all of us to a higher state of mind. This is the spirit of this movie to me. Just let everyone be the best person they are, no matter how much, if any, their orientation differs from their stereotype. I rooted for Yentl, as the under-dog, to succeed in her quest for equality and cringed at some of the things she had to put up with in order to stay the course. She may have not changed any one else, but that is not the point. She changed her world, the only one she actually had the stewardship rights.

reviewText: When "Yentl" was first released it proved to be neither the I-told-you-so triumph producer-director-star Barbra Streisand hoped, nor the total failure detractors  gleefully predicted. In years since, "Yentl" has become the punchline for many jokes, particularly from men who were dragged to see it with their wives or girlfriends, but most of those jokes aren't warranted.As a director, Streisand has much to be proud of. She gets stellar performances from co-stars Mandy Patinkin and Amy Irving (Streisand has proven herself to be an actor's director), the photography is lush and she makes the non-commercial story quite compelling. The movie's main weakness, though, is Streisand's work in front of the camera. Being miscast is nothing new for the star of "Hello, Dolly!" and "A Star is Born," but usually she's buoyed by her star power. In "Yentl," that star power is a detriment. We never buy Streisand as anyone other than Streisand, and we certainly don't buy her as a boy. "Yentl" needed an actress, not a star.However, not many film actresses have Streisand's voice, and this is a musical, after all. The songs in "Yentl" -- all sung by Streisand; fellow singer Patinkin doesn't even hum along -- function as internal monologues, and as such they work fine in the context of the movie. But this is no "Funny Girl," despite a finale that looks very similar to that movie's "Don't Rain on My Parade" sequence. There are few tunes that will be stuck in your head by the final credits. Turning "Yentl" into a musical seemed more of a concession to the studio, anyway.Despite its shortcomings, and despite what all those snarky husbands and boyfriends say about it, "Yentl" proved Streisand's formidable talents aren't just limited to singing and acting.
summary: A Triumph for the Director, Not the Actress

reviewText: I'm a great fan of Barbra Streisand, and it is obvious that she put her heart and soul into this film. It is beautifully filmed and treats the material with an almost heavy-handed reverence. But try as I might to like "Yentl," I just couldn't.This story has been told, and told, and told. From "Some Like it Hot," to "Victor, Victoria," to "Tootsie," the idea of a woman/man pretending to be a man/woman, only to be faced with the dilemma of falling in love and having to reveal their secret...we have seen this tale so many times. Unfortunately for "Yentl," there is nothing new or surprising in this version of the gender-changing story, and others have done a far better job of telling it. It is as predictable as the moon phases and far less interesting. Not for one minute does Barbra Streisand make a convincing man, and I found myself spending the entire film puzzling that her obvious femininity seemed to be lost on the other characters. Barbra's singing is, of course, wonderful. She truly possesses one of the most powerful and stunning voices in film history. But her incredible voice is wasted on a collection of dull and forgetable songs."Yentl" wants very much to be a classic in the vein of "Funny Girl." The final shot in the film is an obvious attempt to recapture the same magic Streisand gave us as Fanny Brice hitting that massive note at the end of "Don't Rain on My Parade." For me it fell flat along with the rest of the film.I guess even a great talent like Streisand is entitled to a stinker.

reviewText: The general public probably can't imagine how long Barbra Streisand fans have eagerly awaited this DVD set, but from Barbra's  very personal and candid comments in it, she certainly knows and has more than satisfied this particular fan...and I haven't even finished listening to her absorbing feature-length film commentary!  It's difficult to know where to begin touting this marvelous new accomplishment, which bears Barbra's personal stamp from beginning to end.  Basically, Yentl's director, star, producer, and co-writer teaches us how she created the film.  Unlike other Streisand films on DVD, besides offering a shimmering remastered golden "print" of the film and full surround audio, this one is all about the process, Barbra's intriguing process.  Her vision, as portrayed on the screen, only is the product of a series of momentous small projects, which she recounts in new on-camera recollections and illustrates through the fascinating material in her archives.Besides the delicious deleted scenes on disc 1, many of which are quite humorous and perhaps would have altered the tone of the film had they originally been included, disc 2 offers the unique opportunity to see Barbra rehearse the film's musical numbers (her "little videos") alongside Alan & Marilyn Bergman, Michel Legrand, Rusty Lemorande, and other friends and collaborators in their homes.  This footage is the highlight of disc 2, priceless and truly indicative of Barbra's high level of preparation prior to shooting her films.  Those familiar with the film will immediately envision the comparisons in their minds when viewing these rehearsal numbers, so, although nicely edited, the comparisons may be unnecessary.  Instead, I would have enjoyed seeing more raw rehearsal footage like "Tomorrow Night."  There's a montage of Barbra's newly narrated 8 mm European location scouting film which further explores her fascinating creative process regarding the film's natural imagery.  "The Director's Reel" is a featurette introduced by Barbra, which places us on the set when cameras continue rolling for her actors to maintain momentum and save time.  Some of the material on disc 2 was featured in bits and pieces on television for special reports and interview programs when Yentl premiered, but the vast majority has never been seen before.  One previously released song "The Moon and I" demo from Just For The Record (the 1991 box set) is accompanied for the first time by a beautiful storyboard sequence with a nude Yentl bathing in a mikvah.  Another previously unreleased gem is Barbra's demo of "Several Sins A Day," also illustrated by a storyboard sequence, somewhat chaotic and haunting.  The plethora of special features goes on to include more than a hundred publicity photos, many rarely or never published, and an unusually funny and somewhat risqué featurette called "My Wonderful Cast and Crew," which serves as sort of an alternate end credits sequence with a memorable conclusion you'll never forget.  Speaking of Barbra's crew, the DVD case insert reproduces one of Barbra's most cherished possessions - a copy of the June 1982 letter from her London crew defending her from detractors.Indeed, this is the Yentl DVD we've been waiting for!  How many times can we see the movie?  More.  How much can we learn from Barbra Streisand about how she made the movie?  More.  What's wrong with wanting more?  After all, nothing's impossible!
summary: Yentl: What's Wrong With Wanting More?  This Is It!

reviewText: Streisand's film is extremely original and personal and easily one of my three choices for best picture of nineteen eighty-three. It would've been a no-brainer to name this the only one, as best picture, but considering the many wonderful films of that year it would not have been practical. `Yentl' is a story of a young woman who wants to study the Torah and the Talmut, which is forbidden to women. Streisand uses the songs in the story as a state of mind or as the personal voice and private feelings of the character she portrays. This is not a musical in the traditional sense, because the only thoughts shared through song are Yentl's. And the songs are tied to each other in a compositional frame, which don't stray too much into eclectic rhythms or extreme transitions between one song and the other. This choice clearly defines the world of Yentl living inside her torment as opposed to the world outside of Yentl's personal experiences. The photography is lush and the lighting beautifully reflects the feeling of the world this film occupies. It is a truly unique and profound cinematic journey, rarely seen.

reviewText: Shades of high school!  Back then, a good friend took me to see “Yentl” – I’ll admit, with quite a bit of reservation because musicals, even hybrid ones like this, were not my thing – and I enjoyed it.  When I had the chance to see it again, I wondered what effect time might have, but to my pleasant surprise, it’s even better to me now.  Barbra Streisand does (at least) double duty, both ably directing and starring in the story of quietly determined girl who wants nothing more than to follow in her Rebbe father’s footsteps, a daunting task that challenges gender roles and expectations.  “Yentl’s” beautiful cinematography and lighter, comedic approach may set a vastly different tone than in Isaac Bashevis Singer’s original story, from which it also veers in plot and theme, but the production stands on its own, and to call it sumptuous would not be an exaggeration.  Streisand is supported by great cast, including Nehemiah Persoff, Amy Irving, Steven Hill, and even Mandy Patinkin, the last of whom I usually find blah but is good here.  Yes, it’s treacly and at times strains credulity (trying to pass off Streisand as a boy, for instance), but that’s not a bad thing when it works.  “Yentl” may remind audiences of other gender-switching stories, the most obvious of which might be “Mulan” (itself based on Chinese legends dating back to the 4th century), but its overall effect has more in common with “Fiddler on the Roof”  than “Orlando.”  And what of the music?  To be honest, despite Streisand’s celebrated vocals and Michel LeGrand’s lush orchestrations, nothing truly stands out, except one song that is rather too close to “Tonight” from “West Side Story.”  But I may not be the best person to ask about the musical content, even after all these years.

reviewText: I have Waited YEARS For Yentl to be released on DVD(have an old vhs copy that has been played over and over again)!  For the past 5 years there was always rumors that this DVD was going to be released only to have the release date always pushed back because Barbra wanted to get the DVD Just Right! I am sure it will be worth the wait(Definatley worth the price, cant believe I will get this for under $10). This is the GREATEST of all of Barbra's Films and this film is by far the most personal of Barbra's. My all time favorite Streisand song is "A Piece of Sky" and when she sings it in the film, it is one of the all time greatest scenes in Cinema History. I was reading some of the other reviews and Barbra Fans are known for Being Picky(like Barbra herself which is why she took her time in releasing the DVD) and I wasnt surprised to read some of the comments referring to "widescreen vs fullscreen" or "Sound" or "Extras". I myself would take this film on dvd any way I could get it BUT rest assured, the dvd is in widescreen(do they even make fullscreen anymore?), highest quality sound and is loaded with extras(11 deleted scenes + commentary from Streisand herself). I AM GETTING VERKLEMPT!
summary: The GREATEST Of Streisand Films FINALLY Making its DVD Debut!
